{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3147278,"name":"","username":"cmarley","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cmarley/{size}/121111_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T03:44:02.581Z","cooked":"

During practice today, the sun gear inside one of the ring gear stages was completely shredded. We believe it is because the torque of moving the arm back and forth rapidly caused the gear to crack and fall apart. The prototype design was a 900:1 reduction using VersaPlanetary ring gears (10:9:10:1 total), and the arm was attached directly to the output shaft (though it was supported on the other side by an axle and bearing attached to the robot frame).

I‚Äôve seen other teams use a chain/sprocket or a belt system to transfer power from the motor/shaft to the arm, but I don‚Äôt see how this could solve our issue. Rapidly turning the motor in the opposite direction while the arm is moving would still need to be transferred through the belt or chain, and through the gearboxes.

Would increasing the reduction help? Even at 900:1, the arm falls under its own weight, and I don‚Äôt think that backdriving a motor through the gears is good for any component involved.

The current solution is to use the dead axle method (which will relieve stress on the gearbox because the arm is not mounted directly to it), with two belts connecting the arm to the output shaft on both sides of the arm.

Any advice or considerations would be appreciated. I know the method is not perfect, but we do not have much in the way of resources and try to make do as best we can.

  • Christopher, 4681 Programming Mentor
","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T03:44:02.581Z","reply_count":3,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":265,"reads":714,"readers_count":713,"score":1497.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/team-2980-2023-open-source-thread/421348/29","internal":true,"reflection":true,"title":"Team 2980 2023 Open Source Thread","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38592,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 4681 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/1","custom_user_title":"FRC 4681 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3147280,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T03:47:34.798Z","cooked":"

900:1 is an unsupported configuration for VersaPlanetary gearboxes. Take a look at the load ratings guide: https://link.vex.com/vexpro/pdf/VersaPlanetary-LoadRatings

The higher ratio stages have TINY sun gears that are guaranteed to sheer under higher torque loads.

Have you/your team done any kind of engineering analysis to figure out the necessary gearing, or just ‚ÄúI know it needs to be high‚Äù? I highly recommend calculating the torque requirements then working backwards using a tool such as https://reca.lc/

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T03:55:58.644Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":690,"readers_count":689,"score":458.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://link.vex.com/vexpro/pdf/VersaPlanetary-LoadRatings","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":52},{"url":"https://reca.lc/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ReCalc","clicks":21}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":21}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/2","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":21}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":21,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147282,"name":"Skye Leake","username":"Skyehawk","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/skyehawk/{size}/179363_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T03:49:27.666Z","cooked":"

Those tiny little sun gears are not well suited for any major loads, you want a 3:1 or so on the output side.

Now, in terms of overall design, getting the load off of that gearbox is for sure a priority, what you have initially is operating way outside the design window of that gearbox. The dead axle with the chain/belt drive is a much better call (chain would probably be preferable here as it is less likely to slip, making sure you have some way to adjust it with an idler or a cam on a sliding bearing block is also going to really help here)

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T03:53:07.051Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":672,"readers_count":671,"score":224.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/3","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147289,"name":"Nate","username":"ns3517","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ns3517/{size}/8364_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T03:55:13.687Z","cooked":"

Please refer to the load guide mentioned above for these gearboxes. Your best bet would be to make a reduction within that load guide, and then reduce it further with soemthing like gears, belts and pulleys, or sprockets

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T03:55:26.251Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":642,"readers_count":641,"score":218.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"Nate","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25567,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Yeah-Yeah"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/4","custom_user_title":"Yeah-Yeah","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147294,"name":"Tom Line","username":"Tom_Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T04:03:11.052Z","cooked":"

9 and 10:1 versas have a tendency to fail in high torque situations.

Options include:

  1. get an am sport gearbox for your end stage.
  2. Add more stages to the versa, and have lower ratios at the torque end.
  3. Counterbalance your arm using a gas shock or bungy or springs.
  4. Slow the motion of your arm and lower the acceleration rate as well through controls.
  5. Get a rev maxplanetary kit with a 3:1 at the end and feed the versa into it (if you can get one)

3:1 5:1 7:1 9:1 will lower the torque on the 9:1 and remove the often broken 10:1. That sill exceeds anything a versa should geared for, but it might live longer. Put the 9:1 against the motor.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T05:42:01.308Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":6,"reads":623,"readers_count":622,"score":314.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"Tom Line","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":12}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7841,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Team 1498"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/5","custom_user_title":"Team 1498","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":10},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":12,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147305,"name":"Gus Michel II","username":"GeeTwo","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/geetwo/{size}/120962_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T04:31:12.367Z","cooked":"

Actually, my recommendation is both #3 and at least one of the other four (or #3 and a belt/chain reduction after the gearbox(es)).

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T04:43:03.587Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":581,"readers_count":580,"score":176.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"Gus Michel II","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"/tag/3","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7841,"username":"Tom_Line","name":"Tom Line","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tom_line/{size}/236809_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22335,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú "},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/6","custom_user_title":"Somebody Else ‚¨õüü´üü•üüßüü®üü©üü¶üü™‚ñí‚ñí‚¨ú ","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"thinking","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147308,"name":"","username":"cmarley","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cmarley/{size}/121111_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T04:34:41.048Z","cooked":"

Thank you for all the prompt responses!

I did not realize there was a load table, and am rather amused at the state of affairs now. We basically did say ‚ÄúI know it needs to be high‚Äù and aimed for something reasonable. If we have the supplies/space/time to get a chain and sprocket system going, I think that would work best for us. At the very least, I know not to have a 10:1 be our output stage connected directly to the arm.

A counterbalance with a bungy (bungee is more familiar to me) is easy to install, as we have those in the shop, so we will take y‚Äôall up on that suggestion.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T04:34:41.048Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":570,"readers_count":569,"score":149.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":38592,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 4681 Programming Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/7","custom_user_title":"FRC 4681 Programming Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147315,"name":"Fletch","username":"Fletch1373","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/fletch1373/{size}/220073_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T04:49:17.151Z","cooked":"

It might be a little late to start doing the calculations at this point, but I highly recommend going through the exercise of analyzing the mechanics of a design. If you know total mass and center-of-mass (relative to the pivot point), you can calculate torque. Once you know torque, you can calculate back to a reasonable speed range (i.e. probably don‚Äôt want 1000 deg/sec, but probably want more than 2 deg/sec). ReCalc will also factor in motor choice, current limits, efficiency loss, etc. Plug-n-chug is a perfectly valid approach here as well, just to get you in the right range.

I suspect you‚Äôd be fine with something in the 200:1 to 400:1 range for total reduction, though I don‚Äôt know the design of your arm. Try to do 2:1 or 3:1 in a chain reduction to reduce the stages needed for the planetary gearbox. With those numbers, your planetary gearbox would need something between 66:1 and 200:1 (granted, non of that range is within the acceptable load range for a NEO or Falcon500 per the published guide, but it‚Äôs a lot closer than you currently are)

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T04:49:17.151Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":528,"readers_count":527,"score":130.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"Fletch","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.reca.lc/arm","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"ReCalc","clicks":12}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":38592,"username":"cmarley","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/cmarley/{size}/121111_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9105,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/8","custom_user_title":"3181/3015 Mentor | 213/1373 Alum | CSA/FTAA/Jack-of-all-Trades","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147341,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T06:16:35.052Z","cooked":"
cmarley:

and the arm was attached directly to the output shaft

I‚Äôve been doing this a while, and this jumped out at me. Instant source of issue.

cmarley:

I‚Äôve seen other teams use a chain/sprocket or a belt system to transfer power from the motor/shaft to the arm, but I don‚Äôt see how this could solve our issue. Rapidly turning the motor in the opposite direction while the arm is moving would still need to be transferred through the belt or chain, and through the gearboxes.

It does three things. First, it reduces the shock load (chain and belt have a wee bit more stretch, plus whatever you use to tension the chain can help). Second, it reduces what you need in the gearbox itself, which allows you to use some tougher stages. Third, having a decently large sprocket can help spread out the torque on the arm end a little bit.

cmarley:

The current solution is to use the dead axle method (which will relieve stress on the gearbox because the arm is not mounted directly to it), with two belts connecting the arm to the output shaft on both sides of the arm.

The bold part scares me a bit. It‚Äôs doable, but now you‚Äôre adding a decently-sized shaft, with load on both ends. Not ideal. You don‚Äôt get any extra torque from this unless you‚Äôre adding a second motor.

Just for grins:

What motor setup are you guys using for this, currently? A 900:1 reduction seems insanely high to me, almost like you‚Äôre running a 775Pro for the entire arm load. (Note: I don‚Äôt recommend this.)
Also, approximate mass and length would help. Fletch is 100% on the right track here, some math required.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T06:16:35.052Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":516,"readers_count":515,"score":123.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/9","custom_user_title":"#westandwithUkraine","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147346,"name":"Nick.kremer","username":"Nick.kremer","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nick.kremer/{size}/174932_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T06:34:44.096Z","cooked":"
cmarley:

During practice today, the sun gear inside one of the ring gear stages was completely shredded. We believe it is because the torque of moving the arm back and forth rapidly caused the gear to crack and fall apart.

My team, 3512, found ourselves exactly where you are in 2019. We built a carriage arm that used a VP live axle setup with a small gear reduction of the VP to the arm pivot axle. This setup absolutely sucked and broke in every way imaginable:

  • shredded VP gears and housings
  • twisted hex shaft, yes including steel hex shaft
  • sheared hex shafts
  • cracked 20DP hex gears, including steel gears
  • more slop than what was reasonable for software to manage

We tried very hard to learn from the lessons of 2019 and use them in designing our 2023 carriage arm. I laid out some some arm best practices in this thread last month (read the whole thread, lots of good advice):

Beware Long Levers General Forum
To expand on this post, if you are planning to build some sort of arm to tackle this seasons challenges, be careful on how you design said arm. 1/2 Hex shaft can and will bend or shear under high torque loads that a long arm will see. Switching to steel hex shaft won‚Äôt really help. Some robust arm building techniques: Use a dead axel setup where the arm rotates around a static shaft instead of a live axel setup where you rotate the axel Use larger diameter aluminum round tubing (3/4" OD or l‚Ä¶

The biggest 3 pieces of advice I can can give you are:

  • Absolutely do not use VersaPlanetary gearboxes for high torque arms
  • Use a dead axle setup with a round aluminum tube
  • Use tensioned chain for your final reduction, the chain will help absorb shock loads and has substantially higher tooth engagement

Here‚Äôs our 2023 arm which incorporates most of the advice I laid out in the shared link above:

IMG_20230211_1141541920√ó2560 350 KB

IMG_20230211_1141111920√ó2560 407 KB

And here‚Äôs our arm calculations using the KLib Design Accelerator:

Screenshot_20230202-192417~2972√ó656 131 KB

15:1 is the MaxPlanetary
40:12 is the #25H Chain Reduction

A Guide to Designing Robust Robot Arms Technical
Google Doc with Edits for feedback and comments Intro Many teams are trying arms for this season, and it can sometimes get confusing with all the considerations and parts you need to make a well-designed arm. I‚Äôve noticed some attempts at copying 7461‚Äôs arm, and there are some things I didn‚Äôt take note of that might be useful when designing your own. Hopefully, this guide isn‚Äôt too late in the season. Feel free to ask questions or message me if you need help. This guide might have some error‚Ä¶

Slight self promotion, but what motor are you using?

I would recommend using a chain reduction on top as it helps with shock loads. We are running 2 neos on a 72:1 on our arm and have no issues, but if you run like a single 775 you might run into problems.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T06:47:39.421Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":412,"readers_count":411,"score":172.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"david","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/a-guide-to-designing-robust-robot-arms/425684","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"A Guide to Designing Robust Robot Arms","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":43066,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"alum | i run frcdesign.org"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/11","custom_user_title":"alum | i run frcdesign.org","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147380,"name":"","username":"Thor5090","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thor5090/{size}/226064_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T09:44:13.851Z","cooked":"

We used constant force springs this year and it took a huge load off of everything. They are really strong springs but you can move our arm with one finger.

67e13247-5939-4da6-855b-9fec09925cef1920√ó2560 379 KB

We know the spring print looks canted and that was due to putting a washer as a spacer because the first print was a little off. New print with no washer solved it.
Edit: do not try to put springs that strong on a PLA print. The material used for those print is CF-12 whish is one of the strongest if not the strongest printable material.

Am I the only one intimidated by those springs? It looks dangerous‚Ä¶

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":35,"updated_at":"2023-02-17T11:46:00.439Z","reply_count":4,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":360,"readers_count":359,"score":212.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":427139,"topic_slug":"sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes","display_username":"Ben Edwards","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53198,"username":"Thor5090","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thor5090/{size}/226064_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":8}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":37435,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"EE mentor"},"post_url":"/t/sun-gear-was-destroyed-how-do-i-rotate-a-heavy-arm-from-a-motor-gearboxes/427139/13","custom_user_title":"EE mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":8}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":8,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3147418,"name":"FrankJ","username":"FrankJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/frankj/{size}/5392_2.png","created_at":"2023-02-17T13:19:51.353Z","cooked":"

They will take you eye out. Ideally they should have some sort of guard or at minimum the attachments have a very high factor of safety with hazard training for the people around the robot.

For the OP: The Banebot sport gear boxes sold by Andymark gear boxes I recommend for arms. As others have said, don‚Äôt mount the gear box directly to the arm. Chains or belts will adsorb some of the shock loading. Current limit the motor. With that much reduction you have the power to break things. If you can add something that slips when over loaded.

900:1 sounds like way too high a gearing to me. I personally won‚Äôt design anything that requires much more than 100:1. To make up any additional force I use springs to counterbalance.

Please remember that counterbalancing can negate the effect of gravity but it does not remove inertia from the arm.

There is no substitute for properly-specced motors and gearboxes.
